text:
Washington Square Park (Manhattan): The Washington Memorial Arch in the northern edge of the Park at the foot of Fifth Avenue and viewing northward thru same up this thoroughfare. This structure was completed in April of 1892 at a cost of $128,000. Further details will be found in King's Handbook of New York (1892) on page 158. Buildings on the right and left of this structure face southward on the Park and bear Washington Square North numbers; the Rhinelander being the latter. Note the modern apartment house in View 1. This is at the S.E. corner of Fifth Avenue and E. 8th Street and is titled No. 1 Fifth Avenue. Thru the Arch and in the distance appears the monolithic Empire State Building.

February 24, 1933
Views 2 and 3: Fall 1925

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park (Memorial Arch).

text:
A general (aerial) view north from Bleecker Street, between Thompson and Sullivan Streets, showing at the left, Sixth Ave., north from and including West 3rd., Street. Washington Square Park and the beginning of Fifth Ave., are in the centre, and in the background is Bryant Park.

About 1925.

Fairchild Aerial Service.
title: General view - Bleecker Street - North.

text:
Fifth Avenue, at Waverly Place, Washington Square and southern extremity. The tall building in the background is an apartment house at 1 Fifth Avenue.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

(1)
Washington Square Park, showing the center fountain with the Washington Arch in the background, and children at play in the water.  18-22 Washington Square North, west of Fifth Avenue, are the houses in background.
P.L. Sperr.

(2)
The same; from another angle.
P.L. Sperr.

August 6th, 1932

(3) The same.
P.L. Sperr.

August 6th, 1932
title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - 5th Avenue: Washington Square Park, showing the center fountain with the Washington Arch in the background, with children at play in the water. 18-22 Washington Square North, west of Fifth Avenue, are the houses in background.

text:
Washington Square Park, southwestward towards Thompson Street, at the S. W. corner of which is located the Judson Memorial Baptist Church (erected 1892). The clearing at the S. E. corner is a tennis court. Buildings formerly there (No's. 58-60 Washington Square) were demolished about 1927. Adjoining same is the Alan Seeger house (No. 61). The campanile of the Church of Our Lady of Pompeii (1927) appears in the mid distance.

View 1: July 17, 1935.
View 2: July 1, 1933.
View 3: May 11, 1940.

View 1: July 17, 1935.
View 2: July 1, 1933.

View 1: July 17, 1935.
View 2: July 1, 1933.
View 3: May 11, 1940.

Washington Square Park, the north eastern corner, seen from #1 University Place. A part of this building is shown to the right, and part of the New York University building to the left.

P.L. Sperr.  July 17th, 1935
title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park seen from 1 University Place.

text:
(1) Washington Square Park: A view northward of the Washington Memorial Arch at the head of Fifth Ave. (right) in the northern portion of the Park. This structure, costing $128,000, which was raised by popular subscription, was completed in April 1892. For a further description of same, see Kings Handbook of New York, page 158.

July 17, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a Christmas tree and Fifth Ave. through the Arch.

December 21, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Similar to No. 2, one year later.

December 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park

text:
Washington Square Park: The Garibaldi bronze by G. Turini; presented to the City by the Italians of the United States and erected here in 1888. It stands in the N.E. corner of the park. The apartment house shown is No. 1 Fifth Ave. and forms an interesting contrast.

September 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park

text:
Washington Square South (from left to right), south side, west from but not including West Broadway, to and including Thompson Street, showing the clearance at the S.E. corner of Thompson Street created by the demolition of Nos. 60, 59 and 58, and No. 61 (3½-story house with white doorway) which is the Alan Seeger House. Also shown (right) is Thompson Street, west side, from Washington Square South, to and including West 3rd Street, with a portion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated line on the latter, and the Judson Memorial Church (Baptist) at the S.W. corner of Thompson Street. Note the Alan Seeger Memorial Tree as seen from a point in Washington Square Park.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Supplement:
No. 61 is commonly known as the House of Genius in which lived Theodore Dreiser and Eugene O'Neill, besides the individuals enumerated above. The former lays part of the plot of his famous novel "The Genius" in this house. In the Fall of 1939, this structure is being vacated as the owner finds continued operation unprofitable, and various plans are being suggested.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - West Broadway
